clinical_study.brief_title: Anti-mullerian Hormone in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
clinical_study.official_title: Anti-mullerian Hormone in Pediatric Patients Treated for Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia

brief_summary.textblock: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common childhood malignancy, with current survival rates exceeding 90%. As cure rates improve, increasing attention is focused on survivor quality of life, including fertility. It is generally accepted that cancer treatments in childhood may interfere with gonadal function, reducing the pool of primordial follicles and consequently causing premature menopause in women. Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) levels is a valuable quantitative indicator of ovarian reserve, being directly related to the number of antral follicles. The evaluation of this hormone makes it possible to identify women at risk of early menopause and to propose them interventions for monitoring and preservation of oocytes, allowing girls to be able to have children once they reach adulthood. The objective of this study is to determine ovarian reserve in girls with ALL before and after treatment by means of the evaluation of the AMH assay.

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluation of blood AMH levels before ALL treatment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Within one months from ALL diagnosis
primary_outcome.description: AMH levels will be evaluated in peripheral blood

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluation of blood AMH levels after ALL treatment
primary_outcome.description: AMH levels will be evaluated in peripheral blood

study_pop.textblock: Female less than 18 years of age with ALL

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female less than 18 years of age
- Diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia
- enrollment within the first month after diagnosis
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous treatments with cytostatics drugs
- ALL as a second malignancy
- Syndromic patient or primary hypogonadism
